verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
verses.comment: Eliphaz, one of Job’s friends, begins his second speech. The structure is similar to the first cycle of dialogue.

verses.text: Should a wise man answer with windy knowledge and fill his belly with the east wind?
verses.comment: Eliphaz accuses Job of empty and reckless words, considering ‘east wind’ as destructive—a metaphor for meaningless argument.

verses.text: Should he reason with useless talk, or with words that do not profit?
verses.comment: Eliphaz’s rhetorical question underscores the biblical idea that words have power and consequence (see Prov. 18:21).

verses.text: Indeed, you cast off reverence and hinder devotion before God.
verses.comment: Eliphaz accuses Job of rejecting piety and undermining proper devotion. This points to the importance of maintaining respect for God, and is echoed in the role of liturgy and tradition in public worship.

verses.text: For your iniquity teaches your mouth, and you choose the tongue of the crafty.
verses.comment: Here, Eliphaz claims Job’s own sin is guiding his speech. This connects to spiritual concepts of internal disposition affecting outward words and actions (see Luke 6:45).

verses.text: Your own mouth condemns you, not I; your own lips testify against you.
verses.comment: The motif that one is judged by his own words reappears in New Testament teachings (see Matt. 12:37), linking the Testaments’ emphasis on self-reflection.

verses.text: Are you the first man who was born? Or were you brought forth before the hills?
verses.comment: Eliphaz questions Job’s authority, invoking ancient wisdom. The phrasing recalls the imagery also used for Divine Wisdom in Proverbs 8, which early Christians saw fulfilled in Christ as the eternal Logos.

verses.text: Have you listened in the council of God? And do you limit wisdom to yourself?
verses.comment: Eliphaz asks if Job had special divine revelation. This connects to later biblical themes about prophetic revelation and apostolic teaching authority.

verses.text: What do you know that we do not know? What do you understand that is not clear to us?
verses.comment: The friends claim collective wisdom over individual revelation, hinting at the necessity of a communal understanding of truth.

verses.text: Both the gray-haired and the aged are among us, men older than your father.
verses.comment: Emphasizing tradition and the value of intergenerational wisdom—as seen in Church history as practiced by the early Church Fathers.

verses.text: Are the comforts of God too small for you, or the word spoken gently to you?
verses.comment: God’s comfort often comes through guidance and gentle admonition; these are expressions of God’s providence and means of grace.

verses.text: Why does your heart carry you away, and why do your eyes flash,
verses.comment: Eliphaz questions Job’s passionate response, connecting emotion to error.

verses.text: so that you turn your spirit against God and let such words go out of your mouth?
verses.comment: Speech against God (blasphemy) is considered gravely serious throughout Scripture (cf. Mark 3:29).

verses.text: What is man, that he can be pure? Or one born of woman, that he can be righteous?
verses.comment: The statement reflects the doctrine of original sin—man’s intrinsic inability of self-justification (see Romans 3:10,23).

verses.text: Behold, God puts no trust in his holy ones, and the heavens are not pure in his sight;
verses.comment: Even heavenly beings are not absolutely pure before God. This humility forms the foundation of intercessory practices and the appeal of saints and angels.

verses.text: how much less one who is abominable and corrupt, a man who drinks iniquity like water!
verses.comment: The image ‘drinks iniquity like water’ demonstrates humanity’s inclination toward sin, foreshadowing the need for a Redeemer.

verses.text: I will show you; listen to me; what I have seen I will declare;
verses.comment: Eliphaz appeals to his experience, a common appeal to lived tradition as well as written revelation.

verses.text: what wise men have told, and have not hidden from their fathers,
verses.comment: Oral tradition and teaching handed down—presented here as trustworthy.

verses.text: to whom alone the land was given, and no stranger passed among them.
verses.comment: Eliphaz points to the patriarchal age, a time of ‘pure’ tradition and faith.

verses.text: The wicked man writhes in pain all his days, through all the years that are laid up for the ruthless.
verses.comment: According to Eliphaz, suffering is the consequence of wickedness, a theme balanced elsewhere in Scripture by the idea that the righteous also suffer, as seen most perfectly in Christ.

verses.text: Distress and terror fill his ears; in prosperity the destroyer comes upon him.
verses.comment: Suffering as a byproduct of guilt, and the sudden reversal of fortunes, prefigures the New Testament teaching on divine justice (cf. Luke 12:20).

verses.text: He does not trust in returning from darkness; he is destined for the sword.
verses.comment: Trust in escape is futile for the wicked; contrasts the hope in resurrection given to the righteous.

verses.text: He wanders for bread, saying, ‘Where is it?’ He knows that a day of darkness is ready at his hand.
verses.comment: Restless wandering underscores the spiritual hunger only met ultimately in Christ (cf. John 6:35).

verses.text: Distress and anguish terrify him; they prevail against him, like a king ready for battle.
verses.comment: Despair and inner turmoil are depicted as overwhelming.

verses.text: Because he has stretched out his hand against God and defied the Almighty,
verses.comment: Sin is rebellion against God—a lesson that runs throughout Scripture.

verses.text: running stubbornly against him with a thickly bossed shield;
verses.comment: The image of running against God with one’s own protection highlights the futility of resisting divine authority.

verses.text: because he has covered his face with his fatness and gathered fat on his hips,
verses.comment: A reference to arrogant prosperity, often condemned in wisdom literature (cf. Ps. 73:7).

verses.text: and has lived in desolate cities, in houses that none should inhabit, which were ready to become heaps of ruins;
verses.comment: Deserted places are viewed as an image of divine judgment (cf. Isa. 13:19–21).

verses.text: he will not be rich, and his wealth will not endure, nor will his possessions spread over the earth.
verses.comment: The impermanence of earthly treasure, a recurring biblical warning.

verses.text: He will not escape from darkness; the flame will dry up his branches, and by the breath of God’s mouth he will go away.
verses.comment: God’s breath brings both life and judgment (cf. Gen. 2:7; Isa. 11:4; 2 Thess. 2:8).

verses.text: Let him not trust in emptiness, deceiving himself, for emptiness will be his reward.
verses.comment: Trust in falsehood yields emptiness—a warning anticipating New Testament teaching (e.g., Matt. 7:26–27).

verses.text: It will be paid in full before his time, and his branch will not be green.
verses.comment: Metaphor of the withering branch—compare to Jesus’ teaching in John 15:6 about those not abiding in Him.

verses.text: He will shake off his unripe grape like the vine, and cast off his blossom like the olive tree.
verses.comment: Early loss of fruitfulness points to spiritual consequences for separation from God.

verses.text: For the company of the godless is barren, and fire consumes the tents of bribery.
verses.comment: Godless alliances and corruption lead to destruction. Fire as a symbol of judgment echoes throughout the prophets.

verses.text: They conceive trouble and give birth to evil, and their womb prepares deceit.
verses.comment: Sin begets further sin, as described by the imagery of conception and birth (cf. James 1:15). This ‘chain of sin’ is broken only by redemption—ultimately fulfilled in Christ. The overall message subtly encourages the value of tradition, spiritual authority, and the Church’s means of grace.
